question.title: Trying to make a TTRPG dice roller, program shows no content despite there are no errors
question.body:
I'm trying to make a TTRPG dice roller with Java within a Java FX app. So far, this is what I have: the program skips the try block and shows nothing in the screen, the console shows no errors. Can you help me? I'm coding this for a personal project. I'm also a student, so I don't know much about coding and I try to avoid AI as much as possible.

public class DiceController {

    @FXML
    Label rollResult, separatedDice;
    @FXML
    TextField diceNotationField;
    @FXML
    Button diceRollButton;

    public void roll() {
        try {

            // get text from field
            String diceNotation = diceNotationField.getText();

            // Use a regex tp detect dice notation
            Pattern regex = Pattern.compile("(\\d+)?d(\\d+)(?:([\\+\\*\\/\\-])(\\d+))?");
            Matcher m = regex.matcher(diceNotation);

            String diceQuantity = "";
            String diceSize = "";
            String diceSign = "";
            String diceModifier = "";

            // Call Random to create a random number
            Random rand = new Random();

            // if the dice quantity is null is set to 1
            if (diceQuantity == null || diceQuantity.isEmpty()) {
                diceQuantity = "1";
            }
            
            // regex matcher check
            if (!m.matches()) {
                rollResult.setText("Intruduce a valid dice notation");
            } else if (m.matches()) {
                diceQuantity = m.group(1);
                diceSize = m.group(2);

                
                
                // Create an array to store the result of each dice
                int diceResultArray[] = new int[Integer.parseInt(diceQuantity)];

                // this variable will generate a random number rolling the dice
                int randomResultInDice = 0;

                // this variable stores the total result
                int total = 0;
                
                for (int i = 0; i < Integer.parseInt(diceQuantity); i++) {
                    // generates a random number on the dice,
                    randomResultInDice = rand.nextInt(1, Integer.parseInt(diceSize) + 1);
                    // stores the separate values of each dice's results in an array
                    diceResultArray[i] = randomResultInDice;
                    // sums the result of the separate dice
                    total += randomResultInDice;
                }

                
                // if there's no sign the string stays empty, else, the regex group is
                // recognized and the corresponding operation is performed
                if (diceSign == null || diceSign.isEmpty() && diceModifier == null || diceModifier.isEmpty()) {
                    diceSign = "";
                    diceModifier = "";
                } else {
                    diceSign = m.group(3);
                    diceModifier = m.group(4);

                    // stores the total result of the dice plus the operation corresponding to the
                    // modifier
                    int totalMod = 0;

                    switch (diceSign) {
                    case "+":
                        totalMod = total + Integer.parseInt(diceModifier);
                        rollResult.setText(String.valueOf(totalMod));
                        separatedDice.setText(String.valueOf(Arrays.toString(diceResultArray)));
                        break;
                    case "-":
                        totalMod = total - Integer.parseInt(diceModifier);
                        rollResult.setText(String.valueOf(totalMod));
                        separatedDice.setText(String.valueOf(Arrays.toString(diceResultArray)));
                        break;
                    case "*":
                        totalMod = total * Integer.parseInt(diceModifier);
                        rollResult.setText(String.valueOf(totalMod));
                        separatedDice.setText(String.valueOf(Arrays.toString(diceResultArray)));
                        break;
                    case "/":
                        if (Integer.parseInt(diceModifier) != 0) {
                            totalMod = total / Integer.parseInt(diceModifier);
                            rollResult.setText(String.valueOf(totalMod));
                            separatedDice.setText(String.valueOf(Arrays.toString(diceResultArray)));
                        } else {
                            totalMod = total;
                            rollResult.setText(String.valueOf(total));
                        }
                        
                        break;
                    default:
                        rollResult.setText(String.valueOf(total));
                        separatedDice.setText(String.valueOf(Arrays.toString(diceResultArray)));
                        break;
                    }
                }

            }

        } catch (Exception e) {
            rollResult.setText(e.toString());
            System.out.println(e);
        }
    }
}

FXML file:

Main method of the UI:

import javafx.application.Application;

import javafx.fxml.FXMLLoader;
import javafx.scene.Parent;
import javafx.scene.Scene;
import javafx.stage.Stage;



public class Main extends Application {
    @Override
    public void start(Stage primaryStage) {
        try {
            Parent root = FXMLLoader.load(getClass().getResource("mainView.fxml"));
            Scene scene = new Scene(root);
            primaryStage.setTitle("TTRPG Toolbox");
            scene.getStylesheets().add(getClass().getResource("application.css").toExternalForm());
            primaryStage.setScene(scene);
            primaryStage.show();
        } catch(Exception e) {
            e.printStackTrace();
        }
    }
    
    public static void main(String[] args) {
        launch(args);
    }
}

answers.body:
The basic logic here is wrong.

Note that you initialize your variables as

String diceSign = "";
String diceModifier = "";

Then, before you reassign these to anything else, you do

if (diceSign == null || diceSign.isEmpty() && diceModifier == null || diceModifier.isEmpty()) {
    diceSign = "";
    diceModifier = "";
} else {
    diceSign = m.group(3);
    diceModifier = m.group(4);

    // Process the input
}

Since you assigned both variables the empty string, the if condition will always be true, and so the else clause will never be executed. You should assign the variables the result of parsing the input before you do the test.

Additionally, the boolean logic does not seem correct. AND takes precedence over OR, so your logic is equivalent to

if (diceSign == null || 
    (diceSign.isEmpty() && diceModifier == null) || 
    diceModifier.isEmpty()
    ) {

    // ...
} else {
    // ...
}

which is not what I think you want. To explicitly do what I think you are trying to do, you should have

if ((diceSign == null || diceSign.isEmpty()) && 
    (diceModifier == null || diceModifier.isEmpty()) 
   ) {


} else {

    // Process the input
}

However, processing the input (as you have it coded) relies on inputs for both the sign and the modifier, so you probably just need an "OR" here anyway:

if (diceSign == null || 
    diceSign.isEmpty() ||
    diceModifier == null || 
    diceModifier.isEmpty() 
   ) {


} else {

    // Process the input
}

On the other hand, you seem to want to process the input if no sign or modifier is specified. In that case, the // Process the input logic needs to be outside the if-else block and needs to handle the cases of null or empty sign or modifier anyway. So the entire if-else structure above is probably unnecessary, as shown in the example code below.

A couple of other notes:

  1. use properly typed variables (e.g. int for integer values) where possible
  2. don't repeat code unnecessarily. You call separatedDice.setText(String.valueOf(Arrays.toString(diceResultArray))); for every case. Just call it outside the switch.
  3. Create expensive objects once and reuse them, if that is how they are designed. You should use a single Random object, not create a new one on every roll.
  4. Restrict scope of variables as locally as possible.

Here is a working version of what I think you want:

import javafx.fxml.FXML;
import javafx.scene.control.Button;
import javafx.scene.control.Label;
import javafx.scene.control.TextField;

import java.util.Arrays;
import java.util.Random;
import java.util.regex.Matcher;
import java.util.regex.Pattern;

public class DiceController {

    private final Random rand = new Random();


    @FXML
    private Label rollResult, separatedDice;
    @FXML
    private TextField diceNotationField;
    @FXML
    private Button diceRollButton;

    public void roll() {
       
        // get text from field
        String diceNotation = diceNotationField.getText();

        // Use a regex tp detect dice notation
        Pattern regex = Pattern.compile("(\\d+)?d(\\d+)(?:([+*/-])(\\d+))?");
        Matcher m = regex.matcher(diceNotation);

        // regex matcher check
        if (!m.matches()) {
            rollResult.setText("Introduce a valid dice notation");
        } else {

            String diceQuantityInput = m.group(1);
            int diceQuantity;
            // if the dice quantity is null is set to 1
            if (diceQuantityInput == null || diceQuantityInput.isEmpty()) {
                diceQuantity = 1;
            } else {
                diceQuantity = Integer.parseInt(diceQuantityInput);
            }

            int diceSize = Integer.parseInt(m.group(2));

            // Create an array to store the result of each dice
            int[] diceResultArray = new int[diceQuantity];


            // this variable stores the total result
            int total = 0;

            for (int i = 0; i < diceQuantity; i++) {
                // generates a random number on the dice,
                int randomResultInDice = rand.nextInt(1, diceSize + 1);
                // stores the separate values of each dice's results in an array
                diceResultArray[i] = randomResultInDice;
                // sums the result of the separate dice
                total += randomResultInDice;
            }


            // if there's no sign the string stays empty, else, the regex group is
            // recognized and the corresponding operation is performed
            String diceSign = m.group(3);
            String diceModifierInput = m.group(4);

            // The following is redundant. If the strings are empty, then the default case
            // in the switch will handle them. There is no need to reassign them the empty string in this case.
            // You can modify your switch statement (see below) to explicitly handle the null case.
            // Note that null switch cases are supported in Java 18 and later.
            
//            if (
//                    diceSign == null ||
//                    diceSign.isEmpty() ||
//                    diceModifierInput == null ||
//                    diceModifierInput.isEmpty()
//            ) {
//                diceSign = "";
//                diceModifierInput = "";
//            }


            // stores the total result of the dice plus the operation corresponding to the
            // modifier
            int totalMod;
            switch (diceSign) {
                case "+":
                    totalMod = total + Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput);
                    break;
                case "-":
                    totalMod = total - Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput);
                    break;
                case "*":
                    totalMod = total * Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput);
                    break;
                case "/":
                    if (Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput) != 0) {
                        totalMod = total / Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput);
                    } else {
                        totalMod = total;
                    }
                    break;
                case null:
                default:
                    totalMod = total;
                    break;
            }
            
            // Also consider a switch expression for this, which is quite a bit less verbose:

//                int totalMod = switch(diceSign) {
//                    case "+" -> total + Integer.parseInt(diceModifier);
//                    case "*" -> total * Integer.parseInt(diceModifier);
//                    case "-" -> total - Integer.parseInt(diceModifier);
//                    case "/" -> Integer.parseInt(diceModifier) == 0 ? total : total / Integer.parseInt(diceModifier);
//                    case null, default -> total;
//                };
            rollResult.setText(String.valueOf(totalMod));
            separatedDice.setText(String.valueOf(Arrays.toString(diceResultArray)));

        }

    }
}

Here's a clean, pared-down version of the method using modern Java idioms and with the commented code above removed. In this version I modified the regex pattern slightly to make things a little less verbose.

    public void roll() {

        // get text from field
        String diceNotation = diceNotationField.getText();

        // Use a regex to detect dice notation
        // Note that replacing "(\\d+)?" with "(\\d*)" in the first group
        // ensures that matcher.group(1) never returns null (since the empty string matches).
        Pattern regex = Pattern.compile("(\\d*)d(\\d+)(?:([+*/-])(\\d+))?");
        Matcher m = regex.matcher(diceNotation);

        // regex matcher check
        if (!m.matches()) {
            rollResult.setText("Introduce a valid dice notation");
        } else {

            String diceQuantityInput = m.group(1);
            int diceQuantity;
            // if the dice quantity is empty is set to 1
            if (diceQuantityInput.isEmpty()) {
                diceQuantity = 1;
            } else {
                diceQuantity = Integer.parseInt(diceQuantityInput);
            }

            int diceSize = Integer.parseInt(m.group(2));

            // Create an array to store the result of each dice
            int[] diceResultArray = new int[diceQuantity];

            // this variable stores the total result
            int total = 0;

            for (int i = 0; i < diceQuantity; i++) {
                // generates a random number on the dice,
                int randomResultInDice = rand.nextInt(1, diceSize + 1);
                // stores the separate values of each dice's results in an array
                diceResultArray[i] = randomResultInDice;
                // sums the result of the separate dice
                total += randomResultInDice;
            }

            String diceSign = m.group(3);
            String diceModifierInput = m.group(4);

            int totalMod = switch(diceSign) {
                case "+" -> total + Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput);
                case "*" -> total * Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput);
                case "-" -> total - Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput);
                case "/" -> {
                    int diceModifier = Integer.parseInt(diceModifierInput);
                    yield diceModifier == 0 ? total : total / diceModifier;
                }
                case null, default -> total;
            };
            rollResult.setText(String.valueOf(totalMod));
            separatedDice.setText(Arrays.toString(diceResultArray));

        }

    }

To solve problems like these, you should consider using a debugger. The details of how to do this will vary depending on which IDE you use, but the basic ideas are the same. Try the following steps:

  1. Create a breakpoint in the first line of the roll() method. Typically you do this by double-clicking or right-clicking the line number in the IDE. I use IntelliJ IDEA, and in that if I hover my mouse over the line number for the first executable line (String diceNotation = diceNotationField.getText();) a red circle appears, and clicking on it creates a breakpoint.
  2. Run the application in debug mode. (In IDEA, there is a button next to the "Run" button that has a "bug" icon.)
  3. When running in debug mode, when the execution hits the breakpoint, it will suspend. So when you press the "Roll!" button, execution will temporarily stop.
  4. The IDE will display the current value of all local variables and variables on the heap. So you can inspect the values of things and make sure they are what you expect.
  5. Use the "Step Over" button to step forward one line of code. This will let you see the execution flow (so, for example, in the original you will see that the else { ... } clause is being skipped), as well as seeing how the values of the variables change when the code runs, line by line.

question_comments.body: ... diceSign == null || diceSign.isEmpty() && diceModifier == null || diceModifier.isEmpty() is not the same as ( diceSign == null || diceSign.isEmpty() ) && ( diceModifier == null || diceModifier.isEmpty() ) -- probably both are not what is intended, I would expect diceSign == null || diceSign.isEmpty() || diceModifier == null || diceModifier.isEmpty() -- and again testing before assigning values
sidenotes: diceQuantity should be tested after matching and assignment, not before; no need to call m.matches() a second time; no need to repeat Integer.parseInt(); ...
I added the FXML file, thank you.

An alternative to posting the FXML and application class is to first check if the logic is working the way you want. If not, then simply post a class which performs the logic (with no UI at all) and demonstrates getting the incorrect result. (But either way, post a complete MRE.)

Edit your question and include both your .fxml file and the code which loads it. This will give us the ability to run your program and observe the behavior you describe. (Also, you should replace System.out.println(e); with e.printStackTrace();. Stack traces are critically important when diagnosing problems.)
Create and post a minimal reproducible example.
